summary: The Charlie Kirk Act clarifies U.S. policy regarding the domestic dissemination of information prepared by the U.S. Agency for Global Media (USAGM). It amends the United States Information and Educational Exchange Act of 1948 to outline the circumstances under which USAGM materials created for foreign audiences can be made available in the U.S., specifically after a 12-year delay. It also amends the Foreign Relations Authorization Act to reinforce the ban on USAGM using funds to influence U.S. public opinion and limit distribution of its program material within the U.S.
